Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitally Addressable and Scalable Laser Fabrication of 3D Gradient Index Nanostructures and Nanophotonic Circuits

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the integration of advanced numerical tools with laser nano-manufacturing techniques. The numerical tools, called transformation optics, will be used to calculate three-dimensional structures with pre-determined optical functions. The designed structures will be fabricated by multiple laser beam-enabled patterning techniques. The three-dimensional laser patterns will be controlled by a mini liquid crystal display (LCD) with very high numbers of pixels. The numerical information will be displayed to encode the laser beam pixel by pixel. This will enable high-precision and rapid production of nanostructures with pre-designed optical properties. A large number of functional nanostructures will be produced by rapidly changing the numerical coding information displayed on the mini LCD. The above techniques will also be used to fabricate optical circuits by adding light paths and controlling the light inside.

The results of this research will lead to improvements in the design of optical devices and the development of an advanced laser fabrication capability. These new digital design and fabrication tools will enable the rapid design, verification, and fabrication of functional nanostructures and devices for telecommunication, sensing, and imaging applications. The digital display-enabled laser fabrication technique will drastically simplify the laser nano-manufacturing process and improve the process control. The single laser exposure and large-volume patterning process will reduce the manufacturing cost, making the process industrially and technically attractive. This research will also provide educational opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has fully/partially supported three Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral research associate. Two graduate students have submitted their Ph.D. dissertations. Two high school students from Texas Academy of Mathematics and Sciences at University of North Texas have participated in the research project and submitted their discovery for science fair competitions. PIs have published over 17 journal papers in Optics Express, Scientific Report, Applied Physics Letters, Applied Optics, Micromachine and Journal of Applied Physics, and a number of conference papers. PIs have performed “Do-It-Yourself 3D Printing” outreach activity in the Research and Learning Center at Fort Worth Museum of Science three times. During the event, PIs brought a 3D printer, computer, polymer material, and open source CAD models to the Research and Learning Center. Museum guests were able to print and keep the printed plastic toys.  PIs have been impressed with over 30 guest participants per hour during the event held in the Museum.

During the project period, PIs have achieved fabrication of three-dimensional (3D) photonic crystals using single reflective optics element, single beam and single exposure technique. This technique has significantly simplified optical setup for the photolithography used in the semiconductor industry. The fabricated photonic crystal can potentially be used in optoelectronics.

The spatial light modulator (SLM) has been used as a digitally programmable phase mask. The desired phase profile has been programmed and digitally encoded into SLM pixel-by-pixel. The laser beam was modulated by SLM. For the first time to PI’s knowledge, the relationship between the gray level in the SLM and the phase of the diffracted laser beam from the SLM has been formulated. A structure of single lattice inside dual lattice has been predicted and fabricated. Furthermore, the line defects have been registered into the lattice of photonic crystals, for the first time. These researches pave the way for future parallel nanopatterning of optical circuits.

For the first time, to PIs’ best knowledge, PIs have demonstrated the digital, holographic fabrication of graded photonic super-crystal with dual periodicity, dual basis, and dual symmetry using a programmable SLM and one exposure process. By tuning the diffraction efficiency ratio from the SLM, photonic cavities can also be generated in the graded super-lattice simultaneously through a one-exposure process. A high quality factor of over 1,560,000 for a cavity mode in the graded photonic super-crystal with a large super-cell is predicted by simulations.

These finding can also  have impacts on other disciplines in electronics to photonics and to energy: (a) The fabricated graded photonic super-crystals can be used to improve the light extraction efficiency in organic light emitting devices; (b) The photonic cavity in graded photonic super-crystals has a high quality-factor for an application in laser cavity; (c) Achieved phase engineering of laser beams using SLM can be used for the laser shaping for the optical tweezer.
